'''''100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living''''' is a self-help guide by [[Nigel Cumberland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6978123.Nigel_Cumberland |title=Nigel Cumberland (Author of 100 Things Successful People Do) |publisher=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Nigel-Cumberland/e/B0034P71X2/ref=dp_byline_cont_book_1 |title=Nigel Cumberland: Books, Biogs, Audiobooks, Discussions |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>https://www.hodder.co.uk/search.page?SearchText=nigel+cumberland</ref>
==Publication== The book was published in August 2016 by [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray Learning]] in the UK, a part of [[Hodder & Stoughton]] (imprint of [[Hachette UK]]).<ref>{{cite web|author=Time remaining -- days -- hours -- minutes -- seconds |url=https://www.hodder.co.uk/books/detail.page?isbn=9781473635067 |title=Nigel Cumberland - 100 Things Successful People Do - Hodder & Stoughton |publisher=Hodder.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> The US edition<ref>{{cite web|author=Barnes & Noble |url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/100-things-successful-people-do-nigel-cumberland/1124655804?ean=9781857886627 |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living by Nigel Cumberland, Hardcover | Barnes & Noble® |publisher=Barnesandnoble.com |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> came out in October 2016 published by another Hachette UK imprint, Nicolas Brealey Publishing. The paperback version<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/100-Things-Successful-People-Exercises/dp/1473635055/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr= |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9781473635050: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> was published in the UK in May 2017 with a US edition coming out in late 2017. The book has a foreword written by [[Marshall Goldsmith]]. It has featured in various suggested reading lists in the mainstream media.<ref>http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/health/723684/Self-help-book-selection-Autumn-2016</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jenna Farmer |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/books/non-fiction-books/best-books-for-entrepreneurs-2018-beginners-all-time-a8277266.html |title=9 best books for entrepreneurs |publisher=The Independent |date=2018-03-28 |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref>
Translated editions of the book include in [[Dutch language|Dutch]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Nigel Cumberland (Author) |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/9047010795/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1489115930&sr=8-12&keywords=Nigel+Cumberland |title=100 dingen die succesvolle mensen doen: Slim werken en prettig leven: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9789047010791: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> [[Romanian language|Romanian]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librariaverona.ro/produse/100-de-pasi-pentru-o-viata-de-succes-autor-nigel-cumberland-editura-niculescu/7430 |title=100 DE PASI PENTRU O VIATA DE SUCCES AUTOR NIGEL CUMBERLAND EDITURA NICULESCU - Dezvoltare personala - Libraria Verona - Librarie Online - Carti la preturi mici |publisher=Librariaverona.ro |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> [[Russian language|Russian]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mann-ivanov-ferber.ru/books/ne-zhalej-ni-o-chem/ |title=Не жалей ни о чем (Найджел Камберленд) — купить в МИФе |publisher=Mann-ivanov-ferber.ru |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> and [[Slovak language|Slovak]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.databazeknih.cz/knihy/100-veci-ktore-robia-uspesni-ludia-343943 |title=100 vecí, ktoré robia úspešní ľudia - Nigel Cumberland | Databáze knih |publisher=Databazeknih.cz |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> Upcoming translations include into [[Arabic]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]<ref>http://anthearights.com/html/upload/files/doc_pages/78/bg/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1.pdf</ref> and [[Bengali language|Bangla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|title=সফল ব্যক্তিদের ১০০ জীবনচর্চা|last=Tuba, translator of [[Bengali language|Bangla]] version|first=Bushra Amin|date=|website=প্রিয়.কম|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171120050709/https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|archive-date=2017-11-20|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-10-02|df=}}</ref>
The book is available to be used in schools for the [[visually impaired]] in the United States through the [[Bookshare|bookshare service]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Bookshare: Homepage |url=https://www.bookshare.org/browse/book/1395852?returnPath=L2Jyb3dzZS9sYXRlc3Q/bW9kdWxlTmFtZT1wdWJsaWMmc29ydE9yZGVyPVRJVExFJmFkZGVkPU1PTlRIJmxpbWl0PTEwMCZvZmZzZXQ9MA%3D%3D |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Habits, Mindsets and Activities For Creating Your Own Success Story |publisher=Bookshare |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==Contents== The book's 100 chapters each cover in a couple of pages one of the 100 things that the author suggests successful people do. A reviewer writes: "the book, subtitled Little Exercises For Successful Living, is easily digestible (perhaps even as a tip a day), with each spread over two pages – the first explaining the concept and the second featuring practical exercises and activities to apply it to your life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/the-life/book-review-unlearn-it-all-to-move-ahead |title=Book review: Unlearn it all to move ahead | The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=2016-09-06 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> Another adds: "each secret to success is a powerful reminder of the ways you can make your life – and other's – more satisfied, at work, at home and in your relationships, with your health, wealth and in retirement."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/successful-leaders-little-secrets-659239.html |title=Successful leaders' little secrets - Business - Arabian- Business -.com |publisher=Arabianbusiness.com |date=2017-01-17 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>

He won the 2004 MOBO Award for Best Collaboration with 2Play and Jucxi for So Confused." is a British musician, record producer, and former [[mixed martial artist]]. ==Music career== 2Play is a [[Music of Black Origin Awards|MOBO]] Award–winning record producer and musician.{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/performer/2play|title=2play - Music Charts|publisher=}} He is best known for songs with the Canadian-Indian singer [[Raghav]], as well as collaborations with a number of artists including Jucxi D, [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules and Moni. 2Play first entered the music scene in 1997 as a [[UK garage]] producer under the alias Special T.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/291524-Special-T|title=Special T|publisher=}} He has had two UK [[Top 40|Top 10]] [[hit single]]s: "So Confused" (featuring Raghav and Jucxi) and "It Can't Be Right" (featuring Raghav and Naila Boss).{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 571}} A [[cover version|cover]] of [[Kevin Lyttle]]'s "[[Turn Me On (Kevin Lyttle song)|Turn Me On]]" featuring Raghav and Jucxi appeared as a B-side to the single "So Confused". {{Infobox professional wrestler |name=2 Tuff Tony |image=2 Tuff Tony.jpg |caption=Tony in 2008. |names='''2 Tuff Tony''' |height=6 ft 0<ref name=jcp>{{cite web|url=http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=jcw_profile_2_tuff_tony|title=2 Tuff Tony|publisher=Psychopathic Sports|accessdate=2008-08-29|date=April 22, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214115827/http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=jcw_profile_2_tuff_tony|archive-date=2008-12-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |weight=240<ref name=jcp/><ref name=bs/> |birth_name = Anthony Borcherding |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|06|06|mf=yes}}<ref name=bs/> |birth_place =[[Louisville, Kentucky]]<ref name=jcp/> |resides= Louisville, Kentucky |billed= |children = 2 |trainer=[[The Moondogs (professional wrestling)|The Moondogs]]<ref name="WWD9">{{cite video |people=2 Tuff Tony and Corporal Robinson (Interviewees) |date=2010-09-24 |title=Wrestling with Disaster 9 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d8PnAoomNAw |medium=internet production |publisher=Legit Wrestling |accessdate=2010-09-29 }}</ref> |debut= May 23, 1996<ref name=bs/> |retired= |}} '''Anthony Borcherding'''<ref name=bs>{{cite web|url=http://bodyslamming.com/other/2tuff.html|title=2 Tuff Tony profile|publisher=Bodyslamming.com|accessdate=2008-08-29}}</ref> (born June 6, 1974), better known by his [[ring name]] '''2 Tuff Tony''', is an American [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] best known for his [[hardcore wrestling]] style. Throughout his professional wrestling career, Tony has wrestled for various wrestling promotions, including [[Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South]], [[Combat Zone Wrestling]], [[Big Japan Pro Wrestling]], and [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling]]. He is currently employed by Juggalo Championship Wrestling.
In his professional wrestling career, Tony is an eight-time Heavyweight champion, having won the BBW Wrestling Heavyweight Championship once, ICW Heavyweight Championship once, [[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship]] twice, [[JCW Heavyweight Championship]] three times, and MRW Heavyweight Championship once. In addition to these championships, he has won the [[Dramatic Dream Team]] [[Ironman Heavymetalweight Championship]] once and [[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship]] thrice, the latter of which he is the final recognized champion. Tony is also the 2006 [[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#Double Death Tag Team Tournament 2006|IWA Mid-South Double Death Tag Team Tournament winner]] with [[Mad Man Pondo]].
==Professional wrestling career==
===Early career (1996-1999)=== Tony's friends Robert and Jerry traveled to [[Arkansas]] to train with professional wrestlers [[The Moondogs]] and invited him to come along.<ref name="WWD9"/> After watching several training sessions, Tony was invited into the ring. He soon began training alongside his friends, free of charge, because [[Moondog Spot]] felt that Tony "was a natural for the business."<ref name="WWD9"/> Tony started wrestling in [[Indiana]] in a small bingo hall, where he first met wrestler [[Steve Robinson (wrestler)|Corporal Robinson]].<ref name="WWD9"/> He, Robinson, and [[Mad Man Pondo]] began traveling throughout the country together.<ref name="WWD10">{{cite video |people=2 Tuff Tony and Corporal Robinson (Interviewees) |date=2010-09-27 |title=Wrestling with Disaster 10 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIvaXDWOgOM |medium=internet production |publisher=Legit Wrestling |accessdate=2010-09-29 }}</ref> Video distribution company Smart Mark Video helped the trio gain national exposure.<ref name="WWD10"/>
===Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South (1999-2007)=== Tony began working for [[Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South]] (IWA-MS) in 1999. He wrestled his first match against Rolling Hard, where he was introduced to the [[hardcore wrestling]] style of the company.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio">{{cite video |people=Mr. Wrestling (interviewer), 2 Tuff Tony (interviewee) |date=2011-03-02 |title=JCW's 2 Tuff Tony on Ultraviolent Radio 3-2-2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hhRaIOS28ts |medium=Internet Interview |accessdate=2011-03-17 }}</ref> Seeing that Tony had never wrestled in the hardcore style before, Mad Man Pondo requested to work with him in matches.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> The promotion's owner, [[Ian Rotten]], supported the idea and booked the two in a rivalry.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> Pondo acquainted him to the proper techniques of hardcore wrestling, and Tony later recalled that Pondo "took good care of me" in their matches.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/>
On April 29, 1999, Tony defeated Pondo for the [[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship]].<ref name="IWAHardcore">{{cite web| url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ky/iwams/iwams-hc.html |title=Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South Hardcore Title |accessdate=2011-03-17 |publisher=Puroreso Dojo}}</ref> He lost the championship on May 14 to Pondo, but won it back the following day.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/> The following February he lost the championship, but won the [[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship]] two weeks later.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/><ref name="IWAHeavyweight">{{cite web| url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ky/iwams/iwams-h.html |title=Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South Heavyweight Title |accessdate=2011-03-17 |publisher=Puroreso Dojo}}</ref> On March 4, he defeated Pondo and Delilah Starr to unify the IWA-MS Hardcore and Heavyweight Championships.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/><ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/> Two weeks later, Tony lost the championship.<ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/> He won it for a second time the following March 2, before losing it to Mitch Page a month later.<ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/>
In 2006, Tony and Mad Man Pondo took part in the first [[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#IWA Mid-South Double Death Tag Team Tournament|Double Death Tag Team Tournament]], though they weren't told which team would win the tournament.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> They defeated Children of Pain then Dysfunction and Corporal Robinson to make it to the finals. In the finals, Tony and Pondo defeated Tough Crazy Bastards to be crowned the first Double Death Tag Team Tournament champions.
===Juggalo Championship Wrestling (1999–present)=== In 1997, Tony wrestled for Insane Clown Posse at the event ''ICP's Strangle-Mania Live''.<ref name="BehindthePaint353">{{cite book |last=Bruce |first=Joseph |author2=Hobey Echlin |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |date=August 2003 |edition=2nd |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0974184608 |pages=353–365 |chapter=Life on the Road }}</ref> Two years later, he, Robinson, and Mad Man Pondo wrestled at the Dan Curtis Memorial, an independent wrestling [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#B|booker]] who had recently worked for Insane Clown Posse.<ref name="WWD10"/><ref name="BehindthePaint398">{{cite book |last=Bruce |first=Joseph |authorlink=Violent J|author2=Hobey Echlin |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |date=August 2003 |edition=2nd |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0974184608 |pages=398–413 |chapter=Taking Bumps }}</ref> Several days after the event, Tony, Robinson, and Pondo were booked to wrestle for Insane Clown Posse's first [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling]] show.<ref name="WWD10"/> Video of the event was later released nationally. Tony continued wrestling for Juggalo Championship Wrestling, including matches at the [[Gathering of the Juggalos]] festivals and two other videos released by the company.
Tony went on tour with JCW in 2007 to film the [[internet]] [[Professional wrestling|wrestling]] show [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling#SlamTV!|SlamTV!]], where he was involved in a rivalry with [[Tracy Smothers]].<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1">{{cite video|date=2007-09-18|title=JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1194583|medium=DVD|publisher=Psychopathic Video|location=Royal Oak, Michigan|accessdate=2008-11-15}}</ref> Tracy attacked Tony in the sixth episode, causing Tony to be knocked out of action for several weeks.<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1"/> Per storyline, Smothers was arrested just days before Tony's return on the eighth episode, leaving Tony with no way to seek revenge.<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1"/> Tony was attacked by [[Bull Pain]] at East Side Wars, but later defeated him in a [[Hillerich & Bradsby|Louisville Slugger]] match at [[Bloodymania (2007)|Bloodymania]].<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 2">{{cite video|date=2007-10-30|title=JCW SLAM TV, Volume 2|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1194584/|medium=DVD|publisher=Psychopathic Video|location=Royal Oak, Michigan|accessdate=2008-11-15}}</ref> On January 26, 2008, Tony and [[Violent J]] won the [[JCW Tag Team Championship]]. However, their victory was declared void, stricken from the record, and the title was vacated.<ref name="Jan262008">{{cite web |title=JCW January 26, 2008 |url=http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=18279 |publisher=Cagematch |accessdate=13 August 2008 |language=German}}</ref><ref name="SlamTV2-1">{{cite episode |title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 1 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m1ph1KX5BiQ |series=SlamTV! |credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]] |location=Toledo, Ohio |airdate=2008-06-16 |season=2 }}</ref><ref name="The Main Event Feb 22">{{cite episode |title=Feb 22, 2011|series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wpress/?p=51 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Steve Robinson (wrestler)|Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2011-02-22 |minutes= 3:21:00|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512054432/http://wfuckoffradio.com/the-main-event|archivedate=May 12, 2011 }}</ref>
Tony continued his rivalry with Tracy Smothers into season two of SlamTV! In the first episode, both men faced off in a match which saw Tracy win after a fast count by the referee, who was later revealed as Tracy's [[Legitimacy (family law)|illegitimate]] daughter, [[Mickie Knuckles|Isabella]].<ref name="SlamTV2-1"/> Two weeks later, Tracy caught Isabella listening to [[Boondox]], the rapper who sings Tony's entrance music.<ref name="SlamTV2-3">{{cite episode|title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 3|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VH6s_95TFHA|series=SlamTV!|credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]]|location=Springfield, Illinois|airdate=2008-07-25|season=2}}</ref> The following week, Tony attacked Smothers after his match. Tracy later caught Isabella engaging in sexual actions with Boondox, through storyline, and assaulted him.<ref name="SlamTV2-4">{{cite episode|title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 4|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9B7oNXlKuM|series=SlamTV!|credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]]|location=St. Louis, Missouri|airdate=2008-07-31|season=2}}</ref> Tracy and Isabella Smothers were then scheduled face Boondox and 2 Tuff Tony at [[Bloodymania II]].<ref name="SlamTV2-5">{{cite episode |title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 5 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LT7cmP_w0nQ |series=SlamTV! |credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]] |location=Milwaukee, Wisconsin |airdate=2008-08-04 |season=2 }}</ref> However, Isabella was replaced by [[Bull Pain]] after she injured her leg, and Smothers and Pain lost to Tony and Boondox.
At the 2008 Hallowicked After-Party, Tony joined the group the [[Juggalo World Order]]. On November 9, the Juggalo World Order (Scott Hall, Shaggy 2 Dope, Violent J, 2 Tuff Tony, and Corporal Robinson) "invaded" [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]'s [[Turning Point (2008 wrestling)|Turning Point]] PPV by purchasing front row tickets to the event. They proceeded to promote their faction by flashing their JWO jerseys, which each member had on, before being removed from the building.<ref name="PWTorch Nov 9">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_27798.shtml |last=Caldwell |first=James |title=Scott Hall appears on camera with ICP at tonight's TNA PPV |accessdate=10 November 2008 |publisher=ProWrestlingTorch |date=2008-11-09 }}</ref><ref name="The Main Event Nov 11">{{cite episode|title=November 11, 2008 |series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2008-11-11 |minutes=48:18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126090212/http://www.psychopathicradio.com/site/ |archive-date=January 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> At [[Bloodymania III]], 2 Tuff Tony was defeated by [[Viscera (wrestler)|Viscera]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Loser Leaves Town match|"Loser leaves JCW"]] match with [[Terry Funk]] as special guest referee due to interference by [[Balls Mahoney]].<ref name="The Main Event July 20">{{cite episode|title=July 20, 2010| series=The Main Event| url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15| credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]]| station=WFKO| airdate=2010-07-20|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725115222/http://www.wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15|archivedate=2010-07-25}}</ref> Tony was reinstated two months later under the conditions that he start at the bottom, receive no title matches for several months, and cannot compete at any ''Bloodymania'' events.<ref name="The Main Event July 20"/><ref name="The Main Event March 18">{{cite episode |title=March 18, 2010|series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2010-03-18 |minutes= 1:20:50 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328093423/http://www.wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15|archivedate=2010-03-28}}</ref>
That October at Hallowicked After-Party, Tony debuted under the name 2 Strong John while wearing a [[Wrestling mask|mask]] and wrestled against Balls Mahoney.<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/> At Oddball Bonanza on March 20, 2010, he wrestled as 2 Tuff Tony to take on [[Trent Acid|"Holy" Trent Acid]].<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/> During the match, he debuted his newest finisher, an [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Package piledriver|inverted sitout package piledriver]] which he calls Dick for Dinner.<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/><ref name="pwnewsnow">{{cite web|url=http://www.pwnewsnow.com/2010/icps-juggalo-championship-wrestling-results/ |title=ICP's Juggalo Championship Wrestling Results |author=Ric Stevens |date=2010-03-22 |publisher=PWNewsNow |accessdate=21 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325002718/http://www.pwnewsnow.com/2010/icps-juggalo-championship-wrestling-results/ |archivedate=25 March 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> [[Bloodymania IV]] saw the team of [[Balls Mahoney]] and the masked Hollywood Chuck Hogan defeat the team of Mad Man Pondo and [[Necro Butcher]]. Following the match, Hollywood Chuck Hogan unmasked himself to reveal that he was actually 2 Tuff Tony.<ref name="BloodymaniaIV">{{cite web|title=Gathering of the Juggalos Wrestling Recap! |url=http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=home&cat_id=home#a1 |publisher=Psychopathic Sports |date=2010-09-03 |accessdate=2010-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212220752/http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=home&cat_id=home |archivedate=2010-02-12 }}</ref><ref name="GOTJ2010">{{cite web|title=Violent J's Gathering Report |url=http://www.insaneclownposse.com/general-news/violent-js-gathering-report/ |publisher=Psychopathic Records |date=2008-05-22 |accessdate=2009-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824102809/http://www.insaneclownposse.com/general-news/violent-js-gathering-report/ |archivedate=2010-08-24 }}</ref> Tony then attacked Mahoney, leaving him beat down in the middle of the ring.<ref name="BloodymaniaIV"/><ref name="GOTJ2010"/>
Tony faced [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]] at the 2011 event Monster's Island. Sabu, who recently aligned himself with villainous manager Charlie Brown, defeated Tony and continued to attack him after the match ended.<ref name="MonstersIsland">{{cite web |url=http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=61614 |title=JCW Monster's Island |publisher=Philip Kreikenbohm |accessdate=2011-04-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110513024804/http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=61614| archivedate= 13 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The two wrestled again at Up in Smoke in a match where [[Rob Conway]] was hired by Brown to attack Tony.<ref name="UpinSmoke">{{cite web |url=http://pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=57294&p=2 |title=Complete JCW Up in Smoke Internet PPV Coverage: New JCW Champions Crowned, Sabu, Rhino, Zach Gowen and More |author=Mike Johnson |date=2011-04-20 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> He and [[Rhino (wrestler)|Rhino]] defeated Sabu and Conway at [[St. Andrews Brawl]], where Tony was later named number one contender for the [[JCW Heavyweight Championship]].<ref name="StAndrewsBrawl">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/otherppvs/article_49895.shtml |title=Radican's JCW "St. Andrews Brawl" review 5/4: U-Gene vs. Goodie, Cabana vs. Weedman, Rydas vs. Haters |author=Sean Radican |date=2011-05-07 |publisher= TDH Communications Inc. |accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> At Send in the Clowns, Tony defeated Butler Geeves to become JCW Heavyweight Champion.<ref name="SendintheClowns">{{cite web |url=http://pwinsider.com/article/59486/complete-jcw-send-in-the-clowns-internet-ppv-coverage-new-jcw-champ-crowned-rhino-jimmy-jacobs-officer-colt-cabana-necro-butcher-tracy-smothers-and-more.html?p=1 |title=Complete JCW 'Send in the Clowns' Internet PPV |author=Matt Carter |date=2011-06-30 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref> The following month at Above The Law, Tony lost the championship to [[Colt Cabana|Officer Colt Cabana]].<ref name="Above The Law">{{cite web |url=http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=60046&p=4 |title=Complete Juggalo Championship Wrestling 'Above The Law' iPPV Coverage |author=Matt Carter |date=2011-07-20 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref>
At the Hatchet Attacks PPV on May 26, 2012, 2 Tuff Tony defeated [[Kongo Kong]] to win the vacant JCW Heavyweight Championship, making him champion for a second time.<ref name="HatchetAttacks">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/otherppvs/article_61818.shtml |title=RADICAN'S JCW "HATCHET ATTACKS" iPPV REPORT 5/26 - virtual time coverage from Farmington, N.M. |author=Sean Radican |date=2012-05-26 |publisher=pwtorch.com |accessdate=2012-06-29}}</ref> On October 31, 2013, Tony was defeated by [[Necro Butcher]] in a title match.<ref>http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=103074</ref> On May 4, 2014, Tony defeated Krimson to win the vacant JCW Heavyweight Championship. On April 19, 2015, Tony was defeated by Weedman in a title match.
2 Tuff appears as himself with former JCW tag partner Corporal Robinson in the underground wrestling documentary Wrestling with Disaster, a feature-length film that highlights an indy wrestling show gone horribly awry. The production is currently streaming at youtube.com/LegitProWrestling <ref>|url=//youtu.be/MSg-lhxOhRM|</ref>
===Big Japan Pro Wrestling (2000-2006)=== Tony was brought to [[Big Japan Pro Wrestling]] in 2000 by Mad Man Pondo, at the time the American booker for the company.<ref name="WWD10"/><ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> Tony trained at local [[dojo]]s and helped set up chairs at the company, which earned him the respect of the wrestlers.<ref name="WWD10"/> During his first tour, Tony wrestled in mostly singles matches and learned the Japanese style of wrestling.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> In his third tour, he and Pondo formed the tag team Baka Gaijin, Japanese for Stupid Foreigners.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> The team was well received by both the Japanese crowd and the Japanese wrestlers.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> They continued to wrestle multiple tours together from 2001 to 2006.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/>
==Personal life== Borcherding resides in his hometown of [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. He has one daughter and one son. He has suffered multiple injuries throughout his career, including roughly 30 [[concussion]]s, a split [[artery]] in his wrist, a broken leg, both eyebrows being split, and permanent scarring on his forehead.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> In 2001, Tony and Corporal Robinson signed with [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]], but the company filed bankruptcy that same day.<ref name="WWD10"/> Though they were not in the company long, the duo had become (and still remain) friends with many of the wrestlers.<ref name="WWD10"/>

[[Wu-Elements]] | website = http://www.tha4thdisciple.com }} '''Selwyn Bougard''', now known as '''El-Divine Amir Bey''', better known by his stage name '''4th Disciple''', is a sonic artist and audio engineer who was one of the founding members of [[Killarmy]] and one of the best-known [[List of Wu-Tang Clan affiliates|Wu-Tang-affiliated producers]]. He is the only member of the Wu Elements to have worked on the Clan's first breakthrough album, as a mixer. == Biography == After being a turntablist on the Wu-Tang Clan's debut album, ''[[Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)]]'', 4th Disciple co-produced and helped mix several tracks with the [[RZA]] on the first three Wu-Tang solo ventures by various artists, including co-production for "Sub Crazy" by [[Method Man]], "Damage" by [[Ol' Dirty Bastard]] as well as mixing credits for some of [[Raekwon]]'s ''[[Only Built 4 Cuban Linx...]]'', on the tracks "Criminology," "Guillotine (Swordz)," "Spot Rusherz," and "Wu-Gambinos." 4th Disciple then produced what was at the time only the second Wu-Tang track ever to lack a RZA production credit, when the [[Killah Priest]] solo track "B.I.B.L.E. (Basic Instructions Before Leaving Earth)" was included on [[GZA]]'s ''[[Liquid Swords]]''. This led to five 4th Disciple productions appearing on the double album ''[[Wu-Tang Forever]]''. After producing 15 of the 17 tracks on Killarmy's debut album, ''[[Silent Weapons for Quiet Wars]]'', and contributing significant production to the debut albums of [[Killah Priest]] (''[[Heavy Mental]]'') and [[Sunz of Man]] (''[[The Last Shall Be First (Sunz of Man album)|The Last Shall be First]]''), 4th Disciple's beats continued to appear on the solo work of the Clan members, including Inspectah Deck and Method Man. However, more recently, 4th Disciple has been concentrating his production on Killarmy, Sunz of Man, and their immediate affiliates rather than the Clan itself. {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = A-Love |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Antonella Formosa |alias = A-Love |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1983|3|21}} |birth_place = [[Rome, Italy]] |origin = [[Melbourne]], Australia |Instruments = Vocals |genre = Soul/[[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] |Occupation(s) = Singer-songwriter |years_active = |label = Duality Records
Crookneck Records |Related_acts = |website = }} '''''A-Love''''' is a female Australian-based MC from [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]]. Her debut album, ''Ace of Hearts'' was nominated 'Best Urban Release' in the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2008]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/documents/2008ARIAAwardFinalistsAnnounced.pdf|title=Emerging Artists dominate 2008 ARIA Award nominations|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]]|accessdate=18 December 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081221024218/http://aria.com.au/documents/2008ARIAAwardFinalistsAnnounced.pdf| archivedate= 21 December 2008 | deadurl= no}} ==Biography== A-Love was born Antonella Formosa in Rome, Italy on 21 March 1983. Formosa's father, [[Ric Formosa]], a composer/arranger and an original member (lead guitarist) with the Australian band [[Little River Band]] and her mother, Vicki Formosa, was an [[Rhythm & Blues|R&B]] singer.{{quote|My earliest memories are of my Dad carting me around to different studios to these sessions, and playing on pool tables in old studios.|Antonella Formosa{{cite web|url=http://www.threedworld.com.au/music/features/2007/ALove--From-The-Heart/ |title=A-Love from the heart |publisher=3D World|date=3 December 2007|accessdate=18 December 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}}} She attended [[Hawthorn, Victoria|Hawthorn]] Secondary College, graduating in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://namesdatabase.com/people/FORMOSA/ANTONELLA/63056 |title=Formosa, Antonella |publisher=Names Database |accessdate=18 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714151843/http://namesdatabase.com/people/FORMOSA/ANTONELLA/63056 |archivedate=14 July 2011 |df=dmy }} Whilst her first experiences of playing music were with an all-girl band, which never made any public performances, she also discovered hip hop in high school and soon found herself waxing lyrical over beats.{{quote|Rest assured, if I was a better singer, I'd be a soul singer! [MCing] was just something that I fell in love with in my teens. I've always been heavily into lyricism, no matter what kind of musical style I've been interested in. The fact that hip hop let you just not mince words and be really direct and cram so much more content and originality into your lyrics than singing was the biggest thing for me.|Antonella Formosa}} In January 2000, Formosa met Draino from the [[Puah Hedz]]. He was keen to check out her writing and despite her reluctance, he made her feature on a track.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/ozmusicmonth/s986700.htm |title=Next Crop Artists (2003) A-Love|publisher=[[Triple J]]|accessdate=18 December 2008}} The second track that she had ever recorded was with [[Muph & Plutonic|Muphin]], which later became "Some People" which featured on the album ''Despite the Odds''.{{cite web|url=http://www.heavyweighttv.com/artists.php?artist=A+-+Love |title=Artist Profile – A-Love |publisher=Heavyweight TV |accessdate=18 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080722013050/http://www.heavyweighttv.com/artists.php?artist=A+-+Love |archivedate=22 July 2008 |df=dmy }} She has since appeared numerous times on [[Triple J]]'s 'The Hip Hop Show', [[3PBS|PBS]]' 'The Formula' (now 'Hittin Switches') and 'Auscultation', [[3RRR|RRR]]'s 'Wordburner' and [[RMIT University]]'s [[Student Youth Network|SRA FM]]. She was progressing towards a Bachelor of Arts degree in [[Anthropology]] from [[La Trobe University]] and for two years she was the co-host of a hip hop radio show at La Trobe University. May 2002 marked A-Love's official solo introduction to the Australian hip hop and media circles, with her song "Petty" from the album, ''Culture of Kings Volume 2'' (the first ever Australian hip hop feature album on Triple J). "Petty" was put on medium rotation on [[Triple J]]. Formosa was a winner of the [[Nescafe Big Break]] competition in 2002, earning $20,000 with which to start up an independent record label and distribution company, Duality Records. As time progressed, she juggled the twin responsibilities of building a label and working on her own debut as an artist.{{cite web|url=http://cache.zoominfo.com/CachedPage/?archive_id=0&page_id=1664302048&page_url=%2f%2fnbb.tekgroup.com.au%2fwinners%2f2002%2fantonella_formosa.asp&page_last_updated=8%2f4%2f2006+5%3a12%3a10+AM&firstName=Antonella&lastName=Formosa|title=Hip Hop Artist's career gets a spin in the right direction|publisher=Zoom Info|date=1 January 2002|accessdate=18 December 2008}}{{Quote|I really concentrated on getting the admin and strategic side of the label going, but it just proved to be a bit too hard. I knew that it was either gonna be the music that went or the label – which is where we are now.|Antonella Formosa}} Formosa released her debut album, ''Ace of Hearts'' on 24 November 2007, on Crookneck Records. The album was produced by BVA (Mnemonic Ascent) with additional beats from [[Suffa]] ([[Hilltop Hoods]]) and Jase. Guests include [[Yungun]] (UK), Raph (Mnemonic Ascent), [[Spikey Tee]] (UK) and emerging indigenous MC Jim Blah. It was Triple J's 'Album of the Week' just three days after its release{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/review/album/s2099792.htm |title=A-Love : Ace of Hearts|publisher=Triple J|date=26 November 2007|accessdate=18 December 2008}} and was nominated for the 2008 [[ARIA Awards]] in the category of 'Best Urban Release'.{{quote|The minute that I stepped in the studio with BVA I knew the time was right to record this album. I felt hungry and inspired again, it all fell in place. The result is a bunch of songs with lasting sentiment; real stories about real life.|Antonella Formosa{{cite web|url=http://www.jplay.com.au/JSite/ViewArtist.aspx?ArtistID=3400&ShowFullBio=true|title=A-Love @J Play|publisher=J Play|accessdate=18 December 2008}}}} She was also nominated for two at the [[Jägermeister]] AIR (Australian Independent Record Labels Association) Awards in 2008, in the categories of 'Best New Independent Artist' and 'Best Independent Hip Hop Artist'.{{cite web |url=http://www.airawards.com.au/nominees/nominees-2008 |title=AIR Award Nominees 2008 |publisher=Australian Independent Record Labels Association |accessdate=18 December 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126082019/http://www.airawards.com.au/nominees/nominees-2008 |archive-date=26 January 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|publisher=Billboard.biz|title=Yunupingu Wins AIR Awards Triple|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/e3iebd6a39896504e50fda355ba222fdf10|date=25 November 2008|accessdate=18 December 2008}} Formosa has performed with Mystik Journeymen (US), [[Anticon]], [[Hilltop Hoods]], [[Pegz]], [[MC Layla]], Kowhai, [[Bliss n Eso]], Scarz on 45, MC Que, [[TZU]], Bias B and DJ Brand {{Infobox musical artist | name = A.D.O.R | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Eddie Castellanos | alias = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | origin = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) --> | death_place = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = | instrument = | years_active = <!-- YYYY–YYYY (or –present) --> | label = [[Atlantic Records]] | associated_acts = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''A.D.O.R.''', born '''Eddie Castellanos''', is a U.S. hip hop artist whose work includes the [[Pete Rock]]-produced hit "Let It All Hang Out" ([[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], 1992), and "One for the Trouble" (Atlantic, 1994), produced by [[Marley Marl]]. The latter has been [[sampling (music)|sampled]] extensively in later songs, most famously [[Fatboy Slim]]'s 1998 remix of "Renegade Master" by [[Roger McKenzie|Roger "Wildchild" MacKenzie]].
==Biography==
===Early life and career=== Castellanos was born in [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights, New York City]]. His father was a musician by profession, and as a child Castellanos attended his shows. At six years of age he moved with his family to [[Mount Vernon, New York]], later to be known in hip hop circles as "money earnin' Mount Vernon" due to the preponderance of rap stars it produced.The future A.D.O.R. went to high school there, where he met [[Sean Combs]], [[Heavy D]], Al B. Sure, and [[Pete Rock]]. Becoming interested in hip hop, he took the name A.D.O.R. (standing for both Another Dimension of Rhythm and A Declaration Of A Revolution). Sean Combs, by this time working at [[Uptown Records]], began presenting A.D.O.R.'s demo tapes to record companies. Heavy D's DJ, DJ Eddie F, secured him a management and production deal. In 1992 he recorded his first record, the single "Let It All Hang Out", for [[Atlantic Records]].<ref name=am1/>
==="Let It All Hang Out"=== The musical backing for A.D.O.R.'s raps on "Let It All Hang Out" was by his old friend Pete Rock, by 1992 already an acclaimed producer, and now commonly cited as one of the hip hop genre's best. Stanton Swihart of [[allmusic]] describes the track as an "infectious" outing that was an "instant classic" on release, driven by Rock's "irresistible horn loop" and the "tight flow" of A.D.O.R.'s rhymes. A hit in the summer of 1992, for Swihart its qualities have now proved timeless.<ref name=am1>Stanton Swihart. "[http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:difyxqlhldke~T1 A.D.O.R. Biography]", allmusic, undated.</ref><ref name=am2>Stanton Swihart. "[http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:gbfpxqwjldse A.D.O.R.: Shock Therapy]", allmusic, undated.</ref> HipHopDX calls "Let It All Hang Out" "a certifiable Pete Rock classic", with "delicious horns" that no other producer could emulate.<ref name=dx>J-22. "[http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/reviews/id.370 A.D.O.R. - Classic Bangerz]", hiphopdx, January 19, 2004.</ref> Though most critical commentary focuses on the production, the rapper's contribution is roundly praised; Steve Juon of RapReviews notes in particular that the record established A.D.O.R.'s distinctive, high-pitched register.<ref name=juon>Steve Juon. "[http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2003_12_bangerzv1.html A.D.O.R. :: Classic Bangerz Volume 1 :: Tru Reign Records ] rapreviews, December 9, 2003.</ref>
==="One for the Trouble" and ''The Concrete''=== A.D.O.R. toured with major acts and made television appearances building on the buzz created by "Let It All Hang Out". In 1994 he followed up with a second single, "One for the Trouble", produced by K-Def and the legendary Queensbridge producer [[Marley Marl]]. This record provided the "back once again with the ill behaviour" vocal snippet which dominates [[Fatboy Slim]]'s 1998 hit remix of "Renegade Master" by [[Roger McKenzie|Wildchild]]. "One for the Trouble" signaled that plans were underway for a debut album on Atlantic titled ''The Concrete''. Despite his successful run at the major label, A.D.O.R. was let go from his contract with Atlantic in 1995 without ''The Concrete'' being released, reportedly because of disputes over creative decisions, even though promotional items were released and the catalogue number 82443 was assigned to the release.<ref name=stone>Gabrielle Schafer. "[https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/ador/articles/story/5927916/tru_reign_signs_deal_with_sumthing_distribution Tru Reign Signs Deal With Sumthing Distribution ]", ''Rolling Stone'', January 6, 2000.</ref>
===Tru Reign: ''Shock Therapy''=== A.D.O.R. formed his own record company in 1996: Tru Reign Records. For his fledgling label he immediately recorded and released as a single another Pete Rock track, "Enter the Center". It was a successful venture. Stanton reports that it sold "remarkably well" given its independent, small scale distribution, and received heavy radio play.<ref name=am1/> He considers it the equal of its predecessor "Let It All Hang Out", but Juon goes further, offering that both Rock and Castellanos had improved their respective techniques in the six years between the two tracks. He draws attention to a new-found depth in the lyrical content of A.D.O.R.'s rap, putting this advancement down to maturity and experience in the later record.<ref name=juon/> HipHopDX's reviewer found in "Enter the Center" "more of Pete Rock's understated brilliance".<ref name=dx/> A.D.O.R.'s singles to date were collected on his debut album for Tru Reign, ''Shock Frequency'' (1998). Rock and Marley Marl were joined there by [[Diamond D]] and [[DJ Clark Kent|Clark Kent]], making an impressive roster. "Shock to Bliss" and "Shock Frequency" were reminiscent of Rock's cuts, and almost as good, and Kent's contribution "From the Concrete" completed the album's highlights. The record as a whole betrayed its 1992 roots, though reviewers found this was not a bad thing, even if it did mean that it seemed to lack relevance or urgency in the musical climate of 1998.<ref name=am2/>
===''Classic Bangerz'', ''The Signature of the Ill'', and beyond=== In January 2000, Tru Reign secured a distribution deal with [[Nile Rodgers]]' company Sumpthing Distribution. By this time, A.D.O.R.'s roster at Tru Reign also included artists K The Terrorbull, Nappy Redd & Filthy Rich, and Cristal Lane.<ref name=stone/> A.D.O.R. released the album ''Animal 2000'' in this year. All was quiet until 2003, when he reemerged with the compilation ''Classic Bangers, Vol. 1'', and then an album of new music, ''Signature of the Ill'', in 2005. Both were received favorably by critics, yet the praise was again qualified as it had been with ''Shock Frequency''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s reception: the compilation of old material (which mined ''Shock Frequency'' heavily) ''and'' the collection of new music both seemed throwbacks to simpler times, with lyrics that concentrated on fun and a smooth flow rather than the trickery and internal or polysyllabic rhyme schemes of virtuoso rappers following in the wake of [[Biggie]] or [[Big Pun|Pun]].<ref name=dx/><ref name=juon/><ref>John Teufel . " For the song, Step Up. Castellanos hired Producer and Director Ronald Farnham to make the music video, which was shot in Tampa, Florida. [http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2005_09_signatureof.html A.D.O.R. :: Signature of the Ill :: Tru Reign Records]", rapreviews, September 20, 2005.</ref><ref>Dalia Cohen. "[http://exclaim.ca/musicreviews/generalreview.aspx?csid1=75&csid2=865&fid1=19221 A.D.O.R. : Signature of the Ill]", exclaim.ca, November 2005.</ref> A.D.O.R.'s ''Tru Jewelz and Videotape'' was released in 2008.
==Discography== *''[[The Concrete]]'' (Atlantic, 1994) *''Shock Frequency'' (Tru Reign, 1998) *''Animal 2000'' (Tru Reign, 2000) *''Classic Bangerz, Vol. 1'' (Tru Reign, 2003) *''Signature of the Ill'' (Tru Reign, 2005) * ''Tru Jewelz and Videotape'' (Tru Reign, 2008)

'''Abdelkader Aamara''' ({{lang-ar|عبد القادر ٱعمارة}} - born 28 January 1962, in [[Bouarfa, Morocco|Bouarfa]]) is a Moroccan politician of the [[Justice and Development Party (Morocco)|Justice and Development Party]] and is its Chief Treasurer. On 3 January 2012 he was nominated as the Minister for Industry, Trade and New Technologies in the cabinet of [[Abdelilah Benkirane]]. Between 2013 and 2016 he was the Minister for Energy, Mines, Water and Environment and since 5 April 2017 he has been the minister for Equipment, Transport and Water Logistics in the cabinet of [[Saadeddine Othmani|El Othmani]]. From 2 - 20 August 2018 he also took an interim position as the Minister for Economy and Finance following the firing of [[Mohamed Boussaid]]. <ref name=mad>{{cite web|title=Official bio |url=http://www.maroc.ma/NR/rdonlyres/2DD6E1FB-7DA5-45E8-8525-432BDD558B8B/0/BioAbdelkaderA%C3%A2mara.pdf }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=De Bonnes Sources ministre l'Industrie Abdelkader Amara conduira un Conseil du gouvernement ce jeudi|url=http://www.maghress.com/fr/leconomiste/1893504|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=L'Economiste|date=2012-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Soumaya Bencherki|title=La feuille de route de Abdelkader Amara|url=http://www.maghress.com/fr/lematin/161800|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=Le Matin|date=2012-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mouad Rhandi|title=Abdelkader Amara : "Le code électoral est discriminatoire"|url=http://www.maghress.com/fr/lagazette/11980|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=La Gazette du Maroc|date=2006-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Amine Harmach|title=Abdelkader Aamara, de l'Institut d'agronomie au ministère de l'industrie|url=http://www.maghress.com/fr/aujourdhui/86578|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=Aujourd'hui le Maroc|date=2012-01-30}}</ref> Since 2002 he has served as MP for [[Salé]] (re-elected in 2007, 2011) and is a professor at the Hassan II Institute of Agronomy in [[Rabat]], from which he graduated in 1986<ref name=mad/>.
== Career == A laureate and then, since 1986, professor at the Rabat Hassan II Veterinary and Agronomical Institute, Abdelkader Amara obtained his doctorate in the same year before leaving for France in 1989.
Amara has been a member of the General Secretariat, Treasurer and Former President of the Central Framework Committee of the Justice and Development Party since 1997. He has also been an expert at the World Science Organisation, based in Sweden, for the last ten years.
As a Councillor in the town of Salé since 2002, Amara is also a former President of the Productive Sectors Commission in the Chamber of Representatives and is an ex-member of the chamber's bureau.
As Vice-President of the Justice and Development Party group in the chamber in charge of communications, Amara is also a founding member of the Association of Moroccan Parliamentarians Against Corruption and a former member of the Administrative Commission of the National Higher Education Trade Union.
Amara is also the Vice-President of the World Forum of Islamic Parliamentarians, of which he is a founding member, and founding member of the International Alliance for the Support of Al-Qods and Palestine (Istanbul).
Abdelkader Amara is married and a father of three children.

{{italic title}}{{Infobox book | name = After Man
A Zoology of the Future | image = Thefutureiswild-dixonoriginalbook.jpg | author = [[Dougal Dixon]] | language = English | country = United Kingdom | genre = [[Speculative evolution]] | publisher = Granada Publishing (UK)
[[St. Martin's Press]] (US)
Breakdown Press (2018 edition) | isbn = 978-0586057506 | caption = Cover of a 1998 [[paperback]] edition by [[St. Martin's Press]] | pub_date = 1 January 1981 (UK)
1 September 1981 (US)
29 March 2018 (2018 edition) | media_type = Print (hardback and paperback) | pages = 128 }}'''''After Man: A Zoology of the Future''''' is a 1981 [[speculative evolution]] book written by Scottish geologist [[Dougal Dixon]] and illustrated by several illustrators including Diz Wallis, John Butler, Brian McIntyre, Philip Hood, Roy Woodard and Gary Marsh. The book also features a foreword by [[Desmond Morris]]. ''After Man'' explores a hypothetical future set 50 million years from now, a time period Dixon dubs the "Posthomic", which is inhabited by animals that have [[Evolution|evolved]] from survivors of a [[mass extinction]] succeeding our own time. ''After Man'' used a fictional setting and hypothetical animals to explain the natural processes behind evolution, a concept that proved successful. The success of ''After Man'' spawned two following speculative evolution books (sometimes called the "''After'' trilogy"{{Cite interview|last=Naish|first=Darren|title=Of After Man, The New Dinosaurs and Greenworld: an interview with Dougal Dixon|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/tetrapod-zoology/of-after-man-the-new-dinosaurs-and-greenworld-an-interview-with-dougal-dixon/|access-date=2018-09-21|work=Scientific American Blog Network|language=en}}) which used new fictional settings and creatures to explain other natural processes. ''[[The New Dinosaurs]]'', released in 1988, explained the concept of [[zoogeography]] and [[biogeographic realm]]s through a world in which the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event|Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction event]] never happened and [[non-avian dinosaurs]] were still alive. ''[[Man After Man]]'', released in 1990, focused on [[climate change]] over the next few million years through the eyes of future human species [[Genetic engineering|genetically engineered]] to adapt to it.{{Cite news|url=https://amp.theguardian.com/science/2018/may/30/speculative-biology-understanding-the-past-and-predicting-our-future|title=Speculative biology: understanding the past and predicting our future|last=Lydon|first=Susannah|date=2018-05-30|work=the Guardian|access-date=2018-09-23}} ''After Man'' and Dixon's following books inspired the speculative evolution artistic movement which focuses on speculative scenarios in the evolution of life, often possible future scenarios (such as ''After Man'') or alternative paths in the past (such as ''The New Dinosaurs''). Dixon is often considered the founder of the modern speculative evolution movement.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/9/17437644/after-man-new-edition-evolution-humanity-extinction-dougal-dixon-interview-speculative-biology|title=This book imagines what animals might look like if humans went extinct|last1=Potenza|first1=Alessandra|website=The Verge|accessdate=12 June 2018}} == Summary == [[File:World After Man.jpg|left|thumb|Map of the continents in ''After Man'', having experienced 50 million years of [[continental drift]] since the present day]] ''After Man'' explores Earth 50 million years in the future, hypothesizing what new animals might evolve in the timespan between its setting and the present day. Ecology and evolutionary theory are applied to create believable creatures, all of which have their own binomial names and text describing their behaviour and interactions with other contemporary animals. In this new period of the [[Cenozoic]], which Dixon calls the "Posthomic", [[Europe]] and [[Africa]] have [[African Plate|fused]], closing the [[Mediterranean Sea]]; whereas [[Asia]] and [[North America]] has collided and closed the [[Bering Strait]]; [[South America]] has split from [[Central America]]; [[Australia]] has collided with [[Southern Asia]] (colliding with the mainland sometime in the last 10 million years), uplifting a mountain range beyond the mountains of the [[Far East]] that has become the most extensive and the highest chain in the world, greater even than the [[Himalayas]] at their zenith 50 million years ago; and parts of eastern Africa have [[East African Rift|split off]] to form a new island called [[Lemuria (continent)|Lemuria]]. Other volcanic islands have been added, such as the Pacaus [[archipelago]] and Batavia. Over a hundred future animal species are described and illustrated in the book. Major groups include the "rabbucks", versatile descendants of rabbits filling the ecological niches of [[deer]], [[zebra]]s, [[giraffe]]s and [[antelope]], "gigantelopes", descendants of antelope filling niche held by [[African bush elephant|elephants]], [[giraffes]], [[moose]], [[musk oxen]], [[rhinoceroses]], and other large herbivores and the [[Predation|predatory]] rats, the major group of terrestrial predators and descendants of rats. == Development == As a child, Dixon was inspired by [[H. G. Wells]]' ''[[The Time Machine]]'', particularly the far future creatures featured in the book, to create his own imaginary future animals descended from creatures of the modern day. These animals often served as background characters in Dixon's own retellings of Wells' work. In the 1960s, Dixon was influenced by the contemporary conservationist movements, especially a campaign to save the [[tiger]]s. Dixon began to ponder that should the tiger and other endangered animals go extinct, something would inevitably take their place. After seeing a "Save the Whale" badge on a friend in the late 1970s, the idea materialized again. Dixon devised ''After Man'' as a popular-level book on the processes of evolution that instead of using the past to tell the story projected the processes into the future. After finishing a dummy version of the book, with text and his own illustrations, Dixon took the book to two different publishers in London, both of whom immediately greenlit the project.{{Cite news|url=http://tetzoo.com/blog/2018/9/16/the-dougal-dixon-iafter-mani-event-of-september-2018|title=The Dougal Dixon After Man Event of September 2018|work=Tetrapod Zoology Podcast|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-GB}} When designing the various animals of the book, Dixon looked at the different types of biomes on the planet and what adaptations animals living there have, designing new animals descended from modern day ones with the same set of adaptations. Though Dixon made illustrations of his future animals to pitch the project, the final book used illustrations by other artists due to a publisher decision. Dixon created detailed illustrations that the artists followed in the creation of the final artwork featured in ''After Man''. In March 2018, Breakdown Press published a new edition of the book, updated to reflect modern science relating to evolution. The updated version also features new artwork for some of the animals. == Reception == The first review of ''After Man'' was one made by Professor Barry Cox of [[King's College London]] in a science-based radio programme. Cox's review was extremely negative, but subsequent reviews were highly positive. Reviews in ''[[New Scientist]]'' and ''[[BBC Wildlife]]'' praised the book and Dixon went on [[Publicity Tour|publicity tours]] in the United States and the United Kingdom. ''After Man'' was at the time of its release portrayed in reviews as a book about the extinction of mankind, though Dixon has stated that mankind's end was simply an excuse to discuss evolution, humanity having very little do with the "plot" of the book. In 1982, the book was a finalist for the [[Hugo Award for Best Related Work]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1982-hugo-awards/|title=1982 Hugo Awards|publisher=World Science Fiction Society|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVVDaIgM?url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1982-hugo-awards/|archivedate=2011-05-07|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2010-04-19|df=}} === Legacy === Following the success of ''After Man'', Dixon realized that there was a market for popular-level books which use fictional examples and settings to explain actual factual scientific processes. ''After Man'' had explained the process of evolution by creating a complex hypothetical future ecosystem, the "sequel" ''[[The New Dinosaurs]]'' (1988) was instead aimed at creating a book on [[zoogeography]], a subject the general public was quite unfamiliar with, by using a fictional world in which the [[non-avian dinosaurs]] had not gone extinct to explain the process. ''The New Dinosaurs'' was followed by another project in 1990, ''[[Man After Man]]'', which focused on the future evolution of humanity. Japanese markets were highly interested in ''After Man'', and Japanese adaptations were made of the book, including both a [[Stop motion|stop-motion]] documentary and an [[Animation|animated]] film. To date, Dixon's 2010 speculative evolution book ''Greenworld'', exploring humanity's impact on an alien ecosystem, has only been published in Japan. ''[[The Future Is Wild|The Future is Wild]]'', a 2002 miniseries, features future animals evolving over the course of several million years. Early in its development, Dixon was brought in as a consultant. Dixon designed many of the creatures featured in the programme, some of which are similar to creatures in ''After Man'' (such as the "gannetwhale", a bird similar to the whale-like penguins of ''After Man''), and co-authored the companion book with the producer of the series, John Adams. ''The Future is Wild'' also focused considerably on future environmental changes, something Dixon avoided in ''After Man'' so that readers would at the very least recognize the background inhabited by the various future animals. ''The Future is Wild'' was unable to use Dixon's original creatures as [[DreamWorks SKG]] had bought and owned the rights to ''After Man''. DreamWorks eventually abandoned the project, and the rights were then bought by [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]], though no potential movie adaptation has yet materialized. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:After Man: A Zoology Of The Future}} [[Category:Hypothetical life forms]] [[Category:1981 books]] [[Category:Evolutionary biology literature]] [[Category:Evolution in popular culture]] [[Category:Books about evolution]] [[Category:Speculative evolution]] [[Category:Lemuria]] [[Category:Human extinction]]
