{{Infobox comics species |image = CodaCitadel.jpg |imagesize = |caption = '''Coda Citadel'''
Art by: [[J. Scott Campbell]] |publisher = [[Wildstorm Comics]] |debut = ''[[Wildcats (comics)|WildC.A.T.S.]]'' #1 |debutmo = August |debutyr = 1992 |creators = [[Brandon Choi]]
[[Jim Lee]] |deities = |homeworld = Khera |members = [[Grifter (comics)|Grifter]], [[Nemesis (Wildstorm)|Nemesis]], [[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Zealot]] |powers = [[Superhuman strength]], speed, reflexes, stamina, durability, semi-immortality, superior [[Hand to hand combat|hand-to-hand]] and weapons combat skills |subcat = |altcat = |alttop = y |sortkey = Coda }} The '''Coda''' is a group of [[fictional]] female [[warrior]]s in [[Wildstorm]] [[comic book|comics]]. The Coda first appeared in ''[[WildC.A.T.S.]]'' volume 1 #1 (August, 1992) and were created by [[Brandon Choi]] and [[Jim Lee]]. ==Fictional background== The Coda are a particular race of all female aliens who live on the planet Khera. They are trained in their own unique form of martial arts. Their weapon of choice is the Clef Blade, a weapon resembling a harpoon or a lance, though they often wield swords or even modern firearms. Coda warriors usually wear red markings on their face. A sign (usually a circle) on the forehead and stripes on the cheeks) depicting their ranking within the sisterhood. A second class group of Coda warriors of different species have formed on various planets, carrying the blood of original Coda warriors only. ===Khera=== The Coda was founded on the planet Khera, home to the [[Kherubim]]. The Kherubim were a race blessed with longevity, but the downside was that they had become nearly infertile. Childbirth was a great honor and therefore every Kheran had to participate in a ritual in which a Kheran female and a Kheran male had to couple once. Should the female become pregnant and give birth, she would go on to become a priestess. Otherwise she could do with her life as she pleased. [[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Lady Zannah]] had been selected to mate with [[Mister Majestic|Majestros]] and their union did result in childbirth, the child [[Savant (Wildstorm)|Kenesha]]. Zannah, though, loved being a warrior; so her mother, Harmony, proposed a plan: She would tell her people that Zannah's child had died, and would raise Kenesha as her own daughter. Zannah accepted, and Harmony became a figure of legend, the only Kherubim to have given birth to more than one child in ages. This legend was the foundation of the Sisterhood known as the Coda, a completely female [[caste]] of warriors, devoted to the honor of combat. Their male counterpart is known as the Brotherhood of the Sword. Over the millennia, the Coda would grow in power, and at present they are the second largest political faction within Kherubim society. Only the Pantheon is slightly larger. The Coda's headquarters is Zealot's former home, the Tower of Red Lament. Among the Coda on Khera, there is a small cell of elite assassins called the Skein. They have no known counterpart among the Earthborn Coda. The first rule of The Coda is: ''The weapon is the extension of the flesh, the flesh of the mind, the mind of the soul''. ===Earth=== The Kherubim were at war with the [[Daemonite]]s, another spacefaring race. During a ship-to-ship combat, a Kheran and a Daemonite vessel crashlanded on Earth. Both Zannah and Kenesha were on board this vessel. The Kherubim were physically identical to humans and quickly integrated within human society, inspiring tales of superhuman heroes, gods and angels. The Daemonites had the ability to possess human hosts and inspired tales of possession, demons and monsters. Their war continued underground. To aid them in their war, Zannah, now called Zealot and two of her fellow Coda generals, Andromache and Artemis, started training human Coda Warriors, giving birth to the myth of the Amazons. They established a hidden Coda city on Mt. Themyscira in [[Greece]]. Kenesha took the name [[Savant (Wildstorm)|Savant]], but had no desire to join the Coda. As the Earthborn sisterhood are not born immortals, the immortal members take part in a ''Blood Dance'' with the newer members worthy of being called Coda Warriors. In the ritual they cut each other in a ritualistic dance and rub each other's wounds, thus mingling the blood, transferring the immortal blood into the non-immortal. The blood of a Kherubim, mingled with a human's during a special ritual, gave the gift of longevity to normal humans and this became an important ritual for Earth's Coda. The Kheran Coda sisterhood have been shown to perform this ritual also, but as they are all immortal, their reasons have more to do with the symbolic than with the need for survival. The Coda's Cleft Blades, both on Khera and on Earth, are considered very sacred to the sisterhood. They are only to be used in a death duel or in their ritual Blood Dance. During a battle near Troy (presumably the [[Trojan War]]), Zealot's actions branded her as a traitor to the rest of the Coda, to be killed on sight. The Coda general Andromache took over the role of [[Majestrix]]. Under her rule the Coda began selling their skills to the highest bidders and became less noble warriors and more power hungry conquerors. They also began establishing smaller Coda bases around the world. Though Mt. Themyscira still proved to be the oldest and most sacred of homes to the Amazons, the Coda have also been shown to reside in a massive island off the coast of Africa which they refer to as the Coda Citadel, as discovered by members of [[Gen¹³]].''Gen¹³'' (vol. 2), #3-5 As Zealot was seen as a traitor to the sisterhood, she became a constant target of The Coda for several centuries. [[Image:CodaWarrior.JPG|thumb|[[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Zealot]] displays standard Coda weapons, such as the Cleft Blade]] In the mid 20th century, Zealot trained [[Grifter (comics)|Grifter]] in the fighting style of the Coda, making him the first male Coda. When the Coda discovered this they marked Grifter a target for extermination as they believed the Coda ways are only to be carried by women. By now many Coda were working for the Cabal, an organisation founded by the Daemonites. Zealot, Grifter and Savant all were part of the [[WildC.A.T.s]] and Zealot also eventually trained WildC.A.T.s member [[Voodoo (Wildstorm)|Voodoo]] in the Coda martial arts. The WildC.A.T.s and Coda fought often. The WildC.A.T.s returned once to Khera where Zealot was nearly assassinated by her own Coda Sisters, just to make her a martyr for their cause. Zealot was disgusted with the Sisters betrayal of their ideals and returned to Earth with the other WildC.A.T.s. Several months later on Earth, Zealot apparently died on a mission causing the WildC.A.T.s to disband. She decided that the actions of the Coda on Earth and on Khera proved that the Coda had become corrupt and decided that the corruption had to be destroyed. She set out to single-handedly erase the Coda from the face of the Earth. She killed all Coda in America she could find, but spared Grifter, because of their shared romantic past. She warned him not to follow her. Zealot continued her quest in Europe and destroyed most of the Coda there, but was captured by their top agent, The Grand Sarin. Grifter gathered several allies to save her, resulting in a war between his forces and the Coda. In the end, his small group turned out not to be enough, but Grifter called in the help of former WildC.A.T.s member and his current employer, [[Spartan (comics)|Jack Marlowe]], who used his powers to teleport part of the Mediterranean Sea on top of the Coda, drowning many of them. Majestrix Andromache survived and with her surviving troops she faced Grifter and his friends. At the same time FBI-agent Chandler, whose partner had been killed by the Coda, had found the Coda's armory. Chandler detonated the armory, blowing up the entire Coda base. Grifter and his friends were teleported away by Marlowe in time, but Andromache and her soldiers were caught in the blast. Currently there are only few Earth-born Coda left. Majestrix Andromache was among the Coda fighting Grifter and his allies and died in the explosion. Recently, in the pages of ''Majestic'', [[Mister Majestic]] and Zealot have encountered Kherubim Coda Warriors on Earth. Also the Coda-traitor Charis (known as [[Nemesis (Wildstorm)|Nemesis]]) recently joined forces with the former WildC.A.T.s in the pages of ''Wildcats: Nemesis''. During the ''Wildstorm Armageddon'' story line The few remaining Coda were gathered up by the thought long dead Devin, formerly excommunicated acolyte of their order who survived into obscurity until the end of the world occurred. Gathering up the few remaining Coda survivors of the Post Apocalyptic world to create her own sisterhood, with her as Majestrix, which expanded its numbers through the weary travelers and soccer moms looking for safe respite that only her sect could provide, all while keeping any capable males captured as breeding labor in order to proliferate their ranks; Devin would eventually come into conflict with a past [[Caitlin Fairchild]] and her weathered survivor friends of [[Gen 13]]. ==Notable members== *Andromache, Kheran Majestrix of the Coda on Earth. Presumed dead. *Artemis, a Kheran general who followed Zealot to Earth. *Olympia Atreides, WildC.A.T.S. member and possibly the sole [[Daemonite]] Coda. *Baroness Destine, killed by Zealot. *Christine Blaze, Agent of [[International Operations]], infiltrated the Coda. *Cassandra, Coda warrior stationed in the Himalayas. She killed Susanna Chaste and in return was killed by [[Divine Right (comic)|Max Faraday]] using her life-energy to resurrect Susanna. *Cordelia, Matriarch of the Coda and ruler of Melanesia. Former ally of [[Team 7]]. *Delphae, the Coda mystic/shaman with the power to open teleportation portals. *Devin, disfigured assassin charged to capture Voodoo. Thought to have been expired in the second attempt but survives unto the future World's End event as Majestrix of remaining coda. *The Grand Sarin, Coda assassin in special powered armour. Said to be the best assassin among the Earth-born Coda. Killed by Grifter in [[Ladytron (comics)|Ladytron]]'s body. *[[Grifter (comics)|Grifter]], sole male Coda. *Lady Harmony, mother of Lady Zannah and head of the Kheran Coda sect called the Skein. She was killed in battle. *Sister Maxima is the only known over-weight Coda warrior. She's an earth born Coda and resides at the Coda Citadel off the coast of Africa. *[[Nemesis (Wildstorm)|Nemesis]] (real name: Charis), a member of the Adrastea class from [[Kherubim|Khera]]. *[[Zealot (Wildstorm)|Zealot]], former Majestrix of the Coda of Earth Note: both [[Savant (Wildstorm)|Savant]] and [[Voodoo (Wildstorm)|Voodoo]] have had Coda-training, but neither have devoted themselves enough to be considered true Coda warriors. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{WildCATs}} [[Category:WildCats characters]] [[Category:Female characters in comics]] [[Category:Fictional warrior races]] [[Category:Fictional women soldiers and warriors]] [[Category:Fictional extraterrestrial life forms]] [[Category:DC Comics aliens]]

{{lead too short|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox video game series | title = Creatures | image = Creatures logo.png | platforms = [[Windows]], [[Classic Mac OS]], [[Linux]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]], [[Game Boy Advance]] | platform of origin = Windows, Classic Mac OS | year of inception = 1996 | developer = Creature Labs | publisher = [[Mindscape]] | genre = [[Life simulation game|Life simulation]] | creator = [[Steve Grand (roboticist)|Steve Grand]] }} '''''Creatures''''' is an [[artificial life]] (alife) [[computer program]] series, created in the mid-1990s by English [[computer science|computer scientist]] [[Steve Grand (roboticist)|Steve Grand]] whilst working for the [[Cambridge]] [[video game]]s developer [[Millennium Interactive]]. Gameplay focuses on raising alien creatures known as Norns, teaching them to survive, helping them explore their world, defending them against other species, and breeding them. Words can be taught to creatures by a learning computer (for verbs) or by repeating the name of the object while the creature is looking at it. After a creature understands language, the player can instruct their creature by typing in instructions, which the creature may choose to obey. A complete life cycle is modelled for the creatures - childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and senescence, each with their own particular needs. The gameplay is designed to foster an emotional bond between the player and their creatures. Rather than taking a scripted approach, Creatures series games were driven by detailed biological and neurological simulation and their unexpected results. There were six major Creatures releases from Creature Labs. Between 1996 and 2001, there were three principal games released, the Docking Station add-on (generally referenced as a separate game) and two children's games, and there were three games created for console systems. A sequel named ''Creatures Online'' was in development, with the artificial life technology from Creatures 3 and Docking Station updated to a 3D environment.
==Overview== The program was one of the first commercial titles<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:_vZ4O4mLERcJ:citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi%3D10.1.1.100.8744%26rep%3Drep1%26type%3Dpdf+LINDSEY+HOLT+critical+study+norn&hl=en&gl=au&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESiKpW-yllagk-uKO8f_wsWCvWM6bdgk1t6w98DE37FIVUQbXlROparPfOmv7XaQVzAW0erovrENwZ4Vy6W_1qs8RxNEAIIcogHKOe91zOc_MMju5bd-XlxuYAWmlzSIf-wa085O&sig=AHIEtbReVlSOKkmed7IZEXgADpkhJrVtiA |title=Simulation: Life Inside the Machine |author=Holt, Lindsey |publisher=Docs.google.com |date=2006 |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref> to code [[artificial life|alife]] organisms from the genetic level upwards using a sophisticated [[biochemistry]] and [[neural network]] [[brain]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://utdallas.edu/~maz031000/res/IEEE_Article.pdf |title=Serious Games for Immersive Cultural Training: Creating a Living World |publisher= |work=IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications |date=March–April 2009 |accessdate=2012-10-22 |authors=Marjorie A. Zielke, Monica J. Evans|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.aaai.org/Papers/Symposia/Spring/1999/SS-99-02/SS99-02-017.pdf |title=AI Beyond Computer Games |author=Stern, Andrew |publisher=[[Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence|AAAI]] Technical Report SS-99-02. |year=1999 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> including simulated senses of sight, hearing and touch.<ref name=GrandCliffAAMAS/> This meant that the Norns and their [[DNA]] could develop and "[[evolution|evolve]]" in increasingly diverse ways, unpredicted by the makers. By [[selective breeding|breeding]] certain Norns with others, some traits could be passed on to following generations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/jul/21/business/fi-14868 |title='Creatures' Craze Is Now the Norn - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=1997-07-21 |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref> The Norns turned out to behave similarly to living creatures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agent.ai/doc/upload/200302/tayl97.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029194858/http://www.agent.ai/doc/upload/200302/tayl97.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-10-29 |title=Three ways to get A-life |publisher= |date=July–August 1997 |accessdate=2012-10-22 |work=IEEE EXPERT}}</ref> Sight is simulated by having a group of neurons representing each type of object in the world. When an object belonging to this type is in front of the creature ('within eyesight'), the neuron becomes active and the creature can 'see' the object.<ref name=GrandCliffAAMAS/> The Norns possess simulated [[drive theory|biological drives]] which give punishment when they are raised, and reward when they are lowered. The model for Norns' decision-making process is [[Behaviorist]] and based on Norns learning how to reduce their drives.<ref name="autogenerated1996"/> Dickinson and Balleine state that while this stimulus-response/reinforcement process makes the creatures seem like they are goal-directed, they are instead 'habit machines' responding in a learned fashion to particular stimuli.<ref>{{cite book|title=The evolution of cognition.Vienna series in theoretical biology |year=2000|publisher=The MIT Press|location=Cambridge, MA, US|isbn=978-0262082860|page=186 |author1=Dickinson, Anthony |author2=Balleine, Bernard W. |editor1=Heyes, Cecilia |editor2=Huber, Ludwig |chapter=Causal cognition and goal-directed action.}}</ref>
Mutations in the genome also occur, allowing new characteristics to appear in the population and potentially be inherited by a future generation.<ref name="NGen23">{{cite magazine |last=|first= |title=Millennium Interactive|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=23 |publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=November 1996|pages=56-57}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Woodcock|first=Steven|title=Game AI: The State of the Industry |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131705/game_ai_the_state_of_the_industry.php?page=2|publisher=Gamasutra |date=20 November 1998 }}</ref> Because the Norns have a lifespan of roughly 40 hours, users could observe the changes that occur over a large number of generations.<ref name="NGen23"/> Faulty genomes can also occur - for example, Norns which cannot see or hear,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://partners.nytimes.com/library/cyber/week/060597creatures.html |title=Coming Soon to the Virtual Pet Store: 'Creatures' Who Live, Eat and Reproduce |author=Richtel, Matt |publisher=Partners.nytimes.com |date=June 5, 1997 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> or immortal Norns due to a hyper-efficient digestion system.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971016000846/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july2.htm |url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july2.htm |title=Creatures July Newsletter Page 2 |publisher=Cyberlife |archivedate=1997-10-16 |accessdate=2012-12-12}}</ref><ref name=TCGDE/> Creatures used the [[emergence|emergent]] approach seen in [[animat]]s, but with the goal of more complex behaviours than [[Animal locomotion|locomotion]].<ref name="grand352">{{cite book|last=Grand|first=Steve|title=Human cognition and social agent technology|year=2000 |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9027251398|page=352 |editor=Dautenhahn, Kerstin|chapter=The Emergence of Personality: How to Create Souls from Cells}}</ref> Grand describes the psychological model of the creatures as being inspired by rats.<ref name="Dr.Frankenstein">{{cite journal|journal=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|date=November 1997|title=The game industry's Dr. Frankenstein|pages=8–13}}</ref> In 2000, Steve Grand described the intelligence level of Norns as being like ants.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Graham-Rowe|first=D.|title=God of the Norns|url=https://www.newscientist.com/nl/0401/stephengrand.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000605223245/http://www.newscientist.com/nl/0401/stephengrand.html|archivedate=2000-06-05|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=2000-04-01|volume=165|issue=2232|pages=42–45}}</ref> Margaret Boden, in 2003, rejected ''Creatures'' as being a form of alien life as the simulated metabolism is concerned with controlling the Norn's behaviour, not on maintaining its 'physical' form.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Boden|first=Margaret A.|title=Alien life: how would we know?|journal=International Journal of Astrobiology|year=2003|volume=2|issue=2|pages=121–129 |doi=10.1017/S1473550403001496|bibcode=2003IJAsB...2..121B}}</ref> In 2011, Steve Grand stated that while the Norns in ''Creatures'' could learn, generalise from past experiences to novel experiences, and react in an intelligent manner to stimuli, they could not think.<ref>{{cite web|author=Grand, Steve |url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/2011/03/06/introduction-to-an-artificial-mind/ |title=Introduction to an artificial mind |publisher=Steve Grand's Blog |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
The [[genetics]] in ''Creatures'' are somewhat different from [[physical anthropology|human genetics]]; they are [[haploid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_genetics_preview_kit2.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19980126091513/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_genetics_preview_kit2.htm |archivedate=1998-01-26 |title=GENETICS PREVIEW KIT - REFERENCE GUIDE |publisher=Cyberlife |date=1998-01-26 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> There is no concept of [[dominant gene]] and [[recessive gene]], much less [[Genetic recombination|recombination]] between [[locus (genetics)|loci]]. Nevertheless, the complexity of the simulated biochemistry meant that Norn behaviour was highly unpredictable.
Among the fans of ''Creatures'' were the [[Oxford]] [[zoology|zoologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]], who called it a "quantum leap in the development of artificial life",<ref>{{cite web|title=Creature Labs Archive |url=http://www.peninsulafilms.com/creaturelabsarch.html |work=Peninsula Films |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425092232/http://www.peninsulafilms.com/creaturelabsarch.html |archivedate=April 25, 2012 }}</ref> and author [[Douglas Adams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/106-2/ |title=My books « Steve Grand's Blog |author=Grand, Steve |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> ''Creatures'' inspired some players to take up careers in the sciences.<ref>{{cite web|author=Grand, Steve |url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/2011/02/28/blowing-my-own-trumpet/ |title=Blowing my own trumpet |publisher=Steve Grand's Blog |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
==History== Originally conceived as a [[desktop pet]] with a brain,<ref name=initialpitch>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/initialpitch.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312005250/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/initialpitch.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |title=Mouse for Windows |author=Grand, Steve |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=November 4, 1992 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Grand later incorporated inspiration from [[The Planiverse]] to pitch a "little computer [[ewok]]s" game,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/ewokspitch.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312005140/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/ewokspitch.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |author=Grand, Steve |title=Little Computer Ewoks |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=16 November 1992 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> like the game ''[[Little Computer People]]''.<ref name=rationale>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/rationale.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312012947/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/rationale.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |author=Grand, Steve |title=Rationale |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=12 December 1993 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Grand wanted players to have a rapport with their creatures, feeling that he should make the creatures seem "genuinely alive" to the player, showing "the 'right' kind of behaviour' in a variety of circumstances. To create this kind of behaviour, Grand felt it was necessary to program the creatures by simulating the building blocks of nature in a [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up]] approach, allowing the complex behaviour to [[Emergence|emerge]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Grand|first=Steve|title=Human cognition and social agent technology|year=2000|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9027251398|page=350|editor=Dautenhahn, Kerstin|chapter=The Emergence of Personality: How to Create Souls from Cells}}</ref> rather than using a [[rule-based system]] approach.<ref name="Dr.Frankenstein"/> Grand later wished to include references to an "English" or Norse mythology, to try to make the world more internally consistent,<ref name=mainhistory>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/creatures_history.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028181218/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/creatures_history.htm |archivedate=2008-10-28 |title=Creatures history |author=Grand, Steve |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=2004-06-04 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref name=mythography>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/mythography.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927203124/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/mythography.htm |archivedate=2008-09-27 |title=Small Furry Creatures: A Mythography |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=8 March 1993 |author=Grand, Steve |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> but found that the team wanted to make the game into a conventional adventure game.<ref name=rationale/> He later decided to scale back on the mythology aspects of the game, focusing instead on the [[artificial life]] point - eventually presenting the game as an artificial [[animal fancy|pet hobby]], which provided some of the impetus to include genetics in the creatures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/pleasureprofit.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927203129/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/pleasureprofit.htm |archivedate=2008-09-27 |author=Grand, Steve |title="Breeding Norns for Pleasure and Profit" — some thoughts |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=1 June 1995 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> ''Creatures'' was developed as a consumer product by [[Millennium Interactive|Millennium]], and was released by [[Mindscape Group|Mindscape]] in 1996. The program was instantly successful,{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} and an [[online community]] of players soon formed, swapping Norns, creating new objects for Albia,<ref name="Jepsen C2"/> sharing tips on how to play the game and anecdotes about unexpected evolutionary changes that they had seen, and even creating new [[Selective breeding|breeds]] of Norn. At one point, the Creatures online community was the largest of its type.
In 1996, ''Creatures'' won an EMMA Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=1996 |title=1996 Winners |publisher=The International EMMA Awards |date=2000-11-21 |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010420074653/http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=1996 |archivedate=2001-04-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/cyberlife_awards2.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970607011020/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/cyberlife_awards2.htm |archivedate=1997-06-07 |title=CREATURES WINS INTERNATIONAL EMMA AWARD |publisher=cyberlife.co.uk |date=1997-06-07 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> Based on sales of 500,000 copies of ''Creatures'' from 1996 through to the second quarter of 1998, it was estimated that at that time, there was a possible global population of up to five million norns.<ref name=TCGDE/>
Development of ''[[Creatures 2]]'' began in Q3 1997.<ref name="Gamasutra C2"/> In 1998, the video games division of [[Millennium Interactive|Millennium]] was sold to Sony Entertainment while those working on alife and ''Creatures'' formed a new company called Cyberlife Technology. Along with continued work on the ''Creatures'' titles, the company did work for industry and the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|British Ministry of Defence]], famously attempting to teach live organisms to fly virtual [[fighter jet]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/ns/980509/features.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990117012705/http://www.newscientist.com/ns/980509/features.html |archivedate=1999-01-17 |title=New Scientist Planet Science: Agents from Albia |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |date=1999-01-17 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stanford.edu/class/sts145/Library/richard.pdf |title=Norn Attacks and Marine Doom |publisher= |author=BIRGIT RICHARD |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> ''Creatures 2'' was nominated in the Artificial Intelligence category of the [[Game Developers Conference]]'s Spotlight Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/Newstand/newsletters/ns_news_stuff_current.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010211202533/http://www.creatures.co.uk/Newstand/newsletters/ns_news_stuff_current.htm |title=Stuff&NORNsense |publisher=Creatures.co.uk |archivedate=2001-02-11 |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref>
In the late 1990s, Grand left Cyberlife to form Cyberlife Research and focus on the production of new alife technologies, including work on a [[robotics|robotic]] life form he called Lucy as well as writing books about his research. The remainder of the company was renamed Creature Labs, and focused on [[video game development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=17_0_6_0_M8 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517100548/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=17_0_6_0_M8 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Creature Labs |publisher=Gamewaredevelopment.com |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref>
Sequels to ''Creatures'', including ''Creatures 2'', ''[[Creatures 3]]'' and the small-children's games ''Creatures Adventures'' and ''Creatures Playground'', were released by Creature Labs in subsequent years. ''Creatures Adventures'' won an EMMA Award in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010421032520/http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=2000 |archivedate=2001-04-21 |title=2000 Winners |publisher=The International EMMA Awards |date=2001-04-21 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> ''Creatures Playground'' was exhibited at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_playground.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20010417093344/http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_playground.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 April 2001 |title=Creatures Playground gets first outing at E3 in Los Angeles |publisher=Creature Labs |date=5 May 2000 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> and nominated for a [[BAFTA award]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/bafta/5_ie/5_NOMINATIONS_2000.htm |title=Interactive Entertainment Awards 2000 |publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts |accessdate=2012-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001214014300/http://www.bafta.org/bafta/5_ie/5_NOMINATIONS_2000.htm |archivedate=2000-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_BAFTA.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20010413232223/http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_BAFTA.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 April 2001 |title=Creatures Playground nominated for BAFTA |publisher=Creature Labs |date=4 October 2000 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> The final major ''Creatures'' release, ''Docking Station'', was made available for download from the company's web site in 2001.<ref name="highlights">{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010522113910/http://www.creatures.co.uk/ |archivedate=2001-05-22 |title=Highlights |publisher=The Creatures Community |date=2001-05-22 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
Development was suspended on future ''Creatures'' games on March 20, 2003, when Creature Labs ceased operations, but development and trademark rights have since been purchased by Gameware Development, Ltd. Gameware has revived the Creatures Developer Network, the shop, the forums, the Docking Station server, and has released many before-purchasable tools and add-ons for free.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/diary.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517015602/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/diary.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Gameware Development |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref>
Gameware staff that previously worked on ''Creatures'' developed a convergent media game for the [[BBC]] called ''[[BAMZOOKi]]''.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/>
In 2004, the ''Creatures'' games have been re-released in combination packs under the names ''Creatures: The Albian Years'' (C1, C2), ''Creatures Exodus'' (C3, DS) and ''Creatures Village'' (CA, CP). The Albian Years, and Exodus include the separate games, whereas Village has merged Adventures and Playground into a single game.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/>
[[Kutoka Interactive]], a Canadian children's software company, has created releases of ''Creatures Exodus'' (Kutoka) and ''Creatures Village'' (Kutoka Kids) that are compatible with both Apple's [[Mac OS X]] and [[Windows XP]].<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/> They were released on 30 September 2005, and can be purchased either directly from Kutoka or from other online stores.
